newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK asks Australia to return man for fraud charges.
newsitem.headline: HK asks Australia to return man for fraud charges.

text.p: The Hong Kong government said on Thursday it was seeking the extradition of a man arrested in Australia in connection with fraudulent share dealings.
Australian Federal Police, accompanied by an officer from Hong Kong's Commercial Crime Bureau, arrested Ronald Tse Chu-fai, 46, in Sydney on Wednesday, the government said.
Tse is the first person to be arrested after a five-year government probe into the Allied Group of Companies.

The probe is believed to be the most expensive commercial investigation in Hong Kong's history, costing the government HK$46 million (US$5.95 million) and with total legal costs for all sides probably passing HK$100 million ($12.9 million), the South China Morning Post reported on Thursday.
The government said it had received legal advice recommending 22 charges be laid against Tse, a former finance director and company secretary at the Allied Group.
Tse left the territory in early 1994.

The charges relate to allegations that a network of offshore companies, including a bank based in the Cook Islands, were used to evade Hong Kong share disclosure laws and to avoid paying for share transactions between 1990 and 1992.
The Allied Group is involved in corporate management and property development.
